channel.title: longer-review-available on Reviews Per Minute
channel.description: Recent content in longer-review-available on Reviews Per Minute

item.title: The March on Rome (Marcia su Roma) (2022) - 97 mins
item.description: Mark Cousins’ calm matter-of-fact narration doesn’t impose parallels between Italian fascist propaganda of the 1920s and today’s modern fascist propaganda but instead allows the obvious parallels to speak for themselves.

item.title: Sanctuary (2022) - 96 mins
item.description: SANCTUARY’s thoughtful depiction of fetish uses the sense of mystery behind sub-dom to bring the audience into the characters’ tangled power dynamics.

item.title: How to Blow Up a Pipeline (2022) - 104 mins
item.description: When I hear motorists and politicians complain about Extinction Rebellion or Just Stop Oil blocking roads, I think they ought to be thankful that the activists are engaging in such milquetoast actions.

item.title: The Artist and the Wall of Death (2022) - 86 mins
item.description: A documentary about the theme of failure that abdicates its responsibility to discuss the actual human costs of failure. Stephen Skrynka is a visual artist obsessed with the Wall of Death, a fairground stunt attraction inside which a motorcyclist drives around the walls of a wooden cylinder.

item.title: Polite Society (2023) - 103 mins
item.description: This year’s EVERYTHING EVERYWHERE ALL AT ONCE: a joyous and hilarious blend of genres that uses irony and maximalist extravagance to speak sincerely about specific lived experience but in a universal way.

item.title: Nightsiren (Svetlonoc) (2022) - 109 mins
item.description: Šarlota (Natália Germáni) returns to the mountain village where she grew up to find she’s an object of suspicion to the villagers.

item.title: The Astronaut (L’Astronaute) (2022) - 110 mins
item.description: A charming celebration of the amateur. Jim Desforges (Nicolas Giraud) is an aeronautical engineer who dreams of launching the first amateur manned space flight.

item.title: Therapy Dogs (2022) - 83 mins
item.description: High school is a shared nightmare. A unique subculture that most of us experienced but which we’ve forgotten the intensity of.

item.title: Other People’s Children (Les Enfants des autres) (2022) - 104 mins
item.description: THE WORST PERSON IN THE WORLD is to thirty-somethings what OTHER PEOPLE’S CHILDREN is to forty-somethings: a mature emotionally resonant romantic comedy-drama that embraces the complexity of modern relationships.

item.title: Tropic (Tropique) (2022) - 108 mins
item.description: A cosmic event strikes the lake where two brothers are swimming, mutilating one and dooming his chances of taking part in Europe’s first space colonisation mission.

item.title: Adopting Audrey (2021) - 92 mins
item.description: There’s a huge generational divide between baby boomers who are rich in capital but emotionally immature and millennials who are poor but emotionally fortified by multiple recessions and 21st century uncertainty.

item.title: Saint Omer (2022) - 123 mins
item.description: Quiet devastation erupts in discrete moments of an otherwise drawn-out trial. Alice Diop shows the processes of institutional justice in all their long, slow, and wordy reality with long shots on one person talking, defending herself, and repeating her life story for the court.

item.title: Tár (2022) - 158 mins
item.description: Cate Blanchett plays Lydia Tár as a charming, authoritative, magnetic, and terrible person. We’re fully immersed in the life and perspective of a deeply unpleasant person and there’s a complex catharsis as the film charts her downfall.

item.title: Enys Men (2022) - 96 mins
item.description: A 1970s BBC British horror that has fallen through time to be released in 2023. The Volunteer (Mary Woodvine) undertakes the same ritual each and every day and it gradually becomes clear that she’s not a botanist but something deeper—something older—and that the flower she’s protecting is something more.

item.title: Eo (2022) - 86 mins
item.description: EO directed by Jerzy Skolimowski uses the language of cinema to push us to empathise with a non-human protagonist and therefore expand our sense of subjectivity to cover the perspective of its titular donkey.
